newsitem.title: UK: UK watchdog criticises OPRAF over consultant fees.
newsitem.headline: UK watchdog criticises OPRAF over consultant fees.

text.p: A government watchdog on Wednesday criticised the Office of Passenger Rail Franchising (OPRAF) for flouting treasury guidance by not setting budgets for the cost of advice from city institutions.

In a report, the National Audit Office said between November 1993 and the end of the 1995-6 financial year, OPRAF spent 39.6 million stg on external advisors, of which 6.6 million related to awarding the first three franchises for passenger services.

Of the total sum, 13.05 million stg went to lawyers Linklaters and Paines, 8.49 million to accountants KPMG, 5.91 million to merchant bank HSBC Samuel Montagu amd 5.32 million to business planning consultants LEK Partnership.
The report says that contrary to Treasury guidance, no cap was set on hourly fees to be paid to the consultants.

"OPRAF did not set budgets for advisers' costs from the outset of the franchising process because they considered that it was not possible to estimate the nature and extent of the advice that they were likely to need or how long the process was likely to take," the report said.

"The National Audit Office consider that they should have done so as recommended in Treasury Guidance to Departments and as a matter of good discipline...so as to have a budget against which to monitor and review expenditure."
The report said that from May of this year, OPRAF have "sought to reduce advisers' costs by setting budgets for the main stages of each franchise award". -- London Newsroom +44 171 542 7767
